\chapter{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{intro:introduction}}\label{\detokenize{intro:introduction-to-oneapi-programming}}\label{\detokenize{intro::doc}}
Obtaining high compute performance on today’s modern computer
architectures requires code that is optimized, power efficient, and
scalable. The demand for high performance continues to increase due to
needs in AI, video analytics, data analytics, as well as in traditional
high performance computing (HPC).

Modern workload diversity has resulted in a need for architectural
diversity; no single architecture is best for every workload. A mix of
scalar, vector, matrix, and spatial (SVMS) architectures deployed in
CPU, GPU, AI, and FPGA {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-accelerator}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{accelerators}}}} is required
to extract the needed performance.

Today, coding for CPUs and accelerators requires different languages,
libraries, and tools. That means each hardware platform requires
completely separate software investments and provides limited
application code reusability across different target architectures.

The oneAPI programming model simplifies the programming of CPUs and
accelerators using modern C++ features to express parallelism with a
programming language called Data Parallel C++ (DPC++). The DPC++
language enables code reuse for the host (such as a CPU) and
accelerators (such as a GPU) using a single source language, with
execution and memory dependencies clearly communicated. Mapping within
the DPC++ code can be used to transition the application to run on the
hardware, or set of hardware, that best accelerates the workload. A host
is available to simplify development and debugging of device code, even
on platforms that do not have an accelerator available.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Not all programs can benefit from the single programming model
offered by oneAPI. It is important to understand if your program can
benefit and how to design, implement, and use the oneAPI programming
model for your program.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{intro:overview}}\label{\detokenize{intro:oneapi-programming-model-overview}}
The oneAPI programming model provides a comprehensive and unified
portfolio of developer tools that can be used across hardware targets,
including a range of performance libraries spanning several workload
domains. The libraries include functions custom\sphinxhyphen{}coded for each target
architecture, so the same function call delivers optimized performance
across supported architectures. DPC++ is based on industry standards and
open specifications to encourage ecosystem collaboration and innovation.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{GUID-5758F720-3C7C-4919-9BB5-F650F88DBD01-low}.jpg}

As shown in the figure above, applications that take advantage of the
oneAPI programming model can execute on multiple target hardware
platforms ranging from CPU to FPGA.


\section{Data Parallel C++ (DPC++)}
\label{\detokenize{intro:data-parallel-c-dpc}}
Data Parallel C++ (DPC++) is a high\sphinxhyphen{}level language designed for data
parallel programming productivity. It is based on C++ for broad
compatibility and uses common, familiar C and C++ constructs. The
language seeks to deliver performance on par with other compiled
languages, such as standard C++ compiled code, and uses C++ class
libraries to allow the compiler to interpret the code and run on various
supported architectures.

DPC++ is based on SYCL* from the Khronos* Group to support data
parallelism and heterogeneous programming. In addition, Intel is
pursuing extensions to SYCL with the aim of providing value to customer
code and working with the standards organization for adoption. For
instance, the DPC++ language includes an implementation of unified
shared memory to ease memory usage between the host and the
accelerators. These features are being driven into a future version of
the SYCL language. For more details about SYCL, refer to version 1.2.1
of the \sphinxhref{https://www.khronos.org/registry/SYCL/specs/sycl-1.2.1.pdf}{SYCL
Specification}.

While DPC++ applications can run on any supported target hardware,
tuning is required to gain the best performance advantage on a given
target architecture. For example, code tuned for a CPU likely will not
run as fast on a GPU accelerator without modification. This guide aims
to help developers understand how to program using the oneAPI
programming model and how to target and optimize for the appropriate
architecture to achieve optimal application performance.


\section{Related Documentation}
\label{\detokenize{intro:related-documentation}}
The following documents are useful starting points for developers
getting started with oneAPI projects. This document assumes you already
have a basic understanding of the oneAPI programming model concepts.

\sphinxhref{https://software.intel.com/en-us/get-started-with-intel-oneapi-linux}{Get Started with Intel oneAPI for
Linux*}

\sphinxhref{https://software.intel.com/en-us/get-started-with-intel-oneapi-windows}{Get Started with Intel oneAPI for
Windows*}

\sphinxhref{https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-oneapi-toolkit-release-notes}{Intel oneAPI Base Toolkit Release
Notes}

\sphinxhref{https://www.khronos.org/registry/SYCL/specs/sycl-1.2.1.pdf}{SYCL*
Specification}
(for version 1.2.1)


\chapter{Programming Model}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/index:programming-model}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/index:oneapi-programming-model}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/index::doc}}
The oneAPI programming model is based upon the \sphinxhref{https://www.khronos.org/registry/SYCL/specs/sycl-1.2.1.pdf}{SYCL*
Specification}.
The specification presents a general heterogeneous compute capability by
detailing four models. These models categorize the actions a developer
needs to perform to employ one or more devices as an accelerator.
Aspects of these models appear in every program that employs the oneAPI
programming model. These models are summarized as:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-model/platform-model:platform-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Platform Model}}}}: Specifies the {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-host}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{host}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-device}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{device}}}}.

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-model/execution-model:execution-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Execution Model}}}}: Specifies the {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-command-queue}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{command queue}}}} and
issuing commands for execution on the device(s).

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-model/memory-model:memory-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Memory Model}}}}: Defines how the host and devices interact with
memory.

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-model/kernel-programming-model:kernel-programming-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Kernel Programming Model}}}}: Defines the code that executes on
the device(s). This code is known as the kernel.

\end{itemize}

The programming language for oneAPI is Data Parallel C++ (DPC++) and
employs modern features of the C++ language to enact its parallelism. In
fact, when writing programs that employ the oneAPI programming model,
the programmer routinely uses language features such as C++ lambdas,
templates, parallel\_for, and closures.
\subsubsection*{Tip}

If you are unfamiliar with these C++11 and later language features,
consult other C++ language references and gain a basic understanding
before continuing.

When evaluating and learning oneAPI, keep in mind that the programming
model is general enough to accommodate multiple classes of accelerators;
therefore, there may be a greater number of API calls required to access
the accelerators than more constrained APIs, such as those only
accessing one type of accelerator.

One of the primary motivations for DPC++ is to provide a higher\sphinxhyphen{}level
programming language than OpenCL™ C code, which it is based upon.
Readers familiar with OpenCL programs will see many similarities to and
differences from OpenCL code. This chapter points out similarities and
differences where appropriate. This chapter also points to portions of
the SYCL Specification for further information.


\section{Sample Program}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/sample-program:sample-program}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/sample-program:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/sample-program::doc}}
The following code sample contains a program that employs the oneAPI
programming model to compute a vector addition. The program computes the
formula \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c = a + b}} across arrays, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b}}, each containing
1024 elements, and places the result in array \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c}}. The following
discussion focuses on sections of code identified by line number in the
sample. The intent with this discussion is to highlight the required
functionality inherent when employing the programming model.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Keep in mind that this sample code is intended to illustrate the four
models that comprise the oneAPI programming model; it is not intended
to be a typical program or the simplest in nature.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

A DPC++ program has the {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-single-source}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{single source}}}} property, which means
the {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-host-code}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{host code}}}} and the {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-device-code}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{device code}}}} can be placed in
the same file so that the compiler treats them as the same compilation
unit. This can potentially result in performance optimizations across
the boundary between host and device code. The single source property
differs from a programming model like OpenCL software technology where
the host code and device code are typically in different files, and
the host and device compiler are different entities, which means no
optimization can occur between the host and device code
boundary. Therefore, when scrutinizing a DPC++ program, the first step
is to understand the delineation between host code and device code. To
be more specific, DPC++ programs are delineated into different scopes
similar to programming language scope, which is typically expressed
via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\}}} in many languages.

The three types of scope in a DPC++ program include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-application-scope}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{application scope}}}}: Code that executes on the host

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-command-group-scope}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{command group scope}}}}: Code that acts as the interface between
the host and device

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-kernel-scope}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{kernel scope}}}}: Code that executes on the device

\end{itemize}

In this example, command group scope comprises lines 45 through 54 and
includes coordination and data passing operations required in the
program to enact control and communication between the host and the
device.

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=622\sphinxpxdimen,height=181\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-D971E8B3-6DE1-407B-B5DE-66656531746A-low}.png}

Kernel scope, which is nested in the command group scope, comprises
lines 50 to 52. Application scope consists of all the other lines not in
command group or kernel scope. Syntactically, definitions are included
from the top level include file; \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sycl.hpp}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{namespace}}
declarations can be added for convenience.

The function of each of the lines and its classification into one of the
four models are detailed as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Lines 2 and 6 \textendash{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{include}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{namespace}} \textendash{} programs employing
the oneAPI programming model require the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{include}} of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cl/sycl.hpp}}. It is recommended to employ the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{namespace}}
statement at line 6 to save typing repeated references into the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cl::sycl}} namespace.

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=622\sphinxpxdimen,height=90\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-D2597DA3-4AB5-48B6-9DC8-9ADEF5DA116F-low}.png}

\item {} 
Lines 20 to 36 \textendash{} Platform model \textendash{} programs employing the oneAPI
programming model can query the host for available platforms and can
either select one to employ for execution or allow the oneAPI runtime
to choose a default platform. A platform defines the relationship
between the host and device(s). The platform may have a number of
devices associated with it and a program can specify which device(s)
to employ for execution or allow the oneAPI runtime to choose a
default device.

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=622\sphinxpxdimen,height=307\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-3FC06310-C983-4891-B125-B2E6F05D6E47-low}.png}

\item {} 
Lines 39 and 45 \textendash{} Execution model \textendash{} programs employing the oneAPI
programming model define command queues that issue command groups.
The command groups control execution on the device.

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=622\sphinxpxdimen,height=129\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-C7465487-3179-41E7-B108-6A7839DF68EE-low}.png}

\item {} 
Lines 41 to 43 and lines 46 to 48 \textendash{} Memory model \textendash{} programs employing
the oneAPI programming model may use buffers and accessors to manage
memory access between the host and devices. In this example, the
arrays, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c}} are defined and allocated on the
host. Buffers, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a\_device}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b\_device}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c\_device}}, are
declared to hold the values from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c}} respectively
so the device can compute the vector addition. The accessors,
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a\_in}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b\_in}}, denote that \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a\_device}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b\_device}} are
to have read only access on the device. The accessor \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c\_res}}
denotes that \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c\_device}} is to allow write access from the device.

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=622\sphinxpxdimen,height=147\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-F7842513-F1B5-4138-BF03-07643FCCCE30-low}.png}

\item {} 
Line 50 to 52 \textendash{} Kernel Programming Model \textendash{} The C++ language
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for}} statement denotes that the code enclosed in its
scope will execute in parallel across the {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-processing-element}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{processing elements}}}} of the device. This example code employs a C++
lambda to represent the kernel.
\begin{quote}

\sphinxincludegraphics[width=622\sphinxpxdimen,height=54\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-10CE50B9-6F91-4968-BDD4-14D157078452-low}.png}
\end{quote}

\item {} 
Line 17 and 56 \textendash{} Scope and Synchronization \textendash{} Memory operations
between the buffers and actual host memory execute in an asynchronous
fashion. To ensure synchronization, the command queue is placed
inside another scope at line 17 and 56 which tells the runtime to
synchronize before the scope is exited as part of the buffer’s
destructors being executed. This practice is used in many programs.

\end{itemize}

When compiled and executed, the sample program computes the 1024 element
vector add in parallel on the accelerator. This assumes the accelerator
has multiple compute elements capable of executing in parallel. This
sample illustrates the models that the software developer will need to
employ in their program. The next sections discuss in more details those
four models: the Platform model, the Execution model, the Memory model,
and the Kernel model.


\section{Platform Model}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/platform-model:platform-model}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/platform-model:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/platform-model::doc}}
The platform model for oneAPI is based upon the SYCL* platform model.
It specifies a host controlling one or more devices. A host is the
computer, typically a CPU\sphinxhyphen{}based system executing the primary portion
of a program, specifically the application scope and the command group
scope. The host coordinates and controls the compute work that is
performed on the devices. A device is an accelerator, a specialized
component containing compute resources that can quickly execute a
subset of operations typically more efficiently than the CPUs in the
system.  Each device contains one or more compute units that can
execute several operations in parallel. Each compute unit contains one
or more {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-processing-element}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{processing elements}}}} that serve as
the individual engine for computation.

A system can instantiate and execute several platforms simultaneously,
which is desirable because a particular platform may only target a
subset of the available hardware resources on a system. However, in the
typical case, a system will have one platform comprised of one or more
supported devices, and the compute resources made available by those
devices.

The following figure provides a visual depiction of the relationships in
the platform model. One host communicates with one or more devices. Each
device can contain one or more compute units. Each compute unit can
contain one or more processing elements.

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] 
\item[] \sphinxincludegraphics[width=800\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-91DDF658-E91E-4017-A8FB-0D957B408C2C-low}.png}
\end{DUlineblock}

The platform model is general enough to be mapped to several different
types of devices and lends to the functional portability of the
programming model. The hierarchy on the device is also general and can
be mapped to several different types of accelerators from FPGAs to GPUs
and ASICs as long as these devices support the minimal requirements of
the oneAPI programming model. Consult the \sphinxhref{https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-oneapi-base-toolkit-system-requirements}{Intel oneAPI Base Toolkit
System
Requirements}
for more information.


\section{Execution Model}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/execution-model:execution-model}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/execution-model:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/execution-model::doc}}
The execution model is based upon the SYCL* execution model. It defines
and specifies how code, termed kernels, execute on the host and the
devices.

The host execution model coordinates execution and data management
between the host and devices via command groups. The command groups,
which are groupings of commands like kernel invocation and accessors,
are submitted to queues for execution. Accessors, which are formally
part of the memory model, also communicate ordering requirements of
execution. A program employing the execution model declares and
instantiates queues. Queues can execute with an in\sphinxhyphen{}order or out\sphinxhyphen{}of\sphinxhyphen{}order
policy controllable by the program. In\sphinxhyphen{}order execution is an Intel
extension.

The device execution model specifies how computation is accomplished
on the accelerator. Compute ranging from small one\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional data to
large multidimensional data sets are allocated across a hierarchy of
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-nd-range}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{nd\sphinxhyphen{}range}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-work-group}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{work\sphinxhyphen{}group}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-sub-group}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{sub\sphinxhyphen{}group}}}}, and
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-work-item}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{work\sphinxhyphen{}item}}}}, which are all specified when the work is submitted
to the command queue.  It is important to note that the actual kernel
code represents the work that is executed for one work\sphinxhyphen{}item. The code
outside of the kernel controls just how much parallelism is executed;
the amount and distribution of the work is controlled by specification
of the sizes of the ND\sphinxhyphen{}range and work\sphinxhyphen{}group.

The following figure depicts the relationship between an ND\sphinxhyphen{}range,
work\sphinxhyphen{}group, sub\sphinxhyphen{}group, and work\sphinxhyphen{}item. The total amount of work is
specified by the ND\sphinxhyphen{}range size. The grouping of the work is specified by
the work\sphinxhyphen{}group size. The example shows the ND\sphinxhyphen{}range size of X * Y * Z,
work\sphinxhyphen{}group size of X’ * Y’ * Z’, and subgroup size of X’. Therefore,
there are X * Y * Z work\sphinxhyphen{}items. There are (X * Y * Z) / (X’ * Y’ *
Z’) work\sphinxhyphen{}groups and (X * Y * Z) / X’ subgroups.

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] 
\item[] \sphinxincludegraphics[width=468\sphinxpxdimen,height=453\sphinxpxdimen]{{GUID-761368A6-499F-4FED-9CC5-19069FBEE179-low}.png}
\end{DUlineblock}

When kernels are executed, the location of a particular work\sphinxhyphen{}item in the
larger ND\sphinxhyphen{}range, work\sphinxhyphen{}group, or sub\sphinxhyphen{}group is important. For example, if
the work\sphinxhyphen{}item is assigned to compute on specific pieces of data, a
method of specification is necessary. Unique identification of the
work\sphinxhyphen{}item is provided via intrinsic functions such as those in the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item}} class (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{global\_id}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{work\_group\_id}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{local\_id}}).

The following code sample launches a kernel and displays the
relationships of the previously discussed \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ND\sphinxhyphen{}range}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{work\sphinxhyphen{}group}},
and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{work\sphinxhyphen{}item}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\subsubsection*{ND\sphinxhyphen{}Range Parallelism Example}

The following discusses the relationships in the use of the ND\sphinxhyphen{}range
in the previous code sample.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
At line 12 is the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\sphinxhyphen{}range}} declaration. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range\textless{}2\textgreater{}}}
specifies a two\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional index space.

\item {} 
The global range is specified by the first argument,
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{range\textless{}2\textgreater{}(N,N)}}, which specifies the overall index space as 2
dimensions with size \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{N}} by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{N}}.

\item {} 
The second argument, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{range\textless{}2\textgreater{}(M,M)}} specifies the local
work\sphinxhyphen{}group range as 2 dimensions with size \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{M}} by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{M}}.

\item {} 
Line 13 employs \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item\textless{}2\textgreater{}}} to reference each work\sphinxhyphen{}item in the
ND\sphinxhyphen{}range, and calls \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_id}} to determine the index in
the global buffer, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bufacc}}.

\end{itemize}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\sphinxhyphen{}group}} is an extension to the SYCL execution model and
sits hierarchically between the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{work\_group}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{work\_item}}. The
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_group}} was created to align with typical hardware resources
that contain a vector unit to execute several similar operations in
parallel and in lock step.


\section{Memory Model}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-model:memory-model}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-model:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-model::doc}}
The memory model for oneAPI is based upon the SYCL* memory model. It
defines how the host and devices interact with memory. It coordinates
the allocation and management of memory between the host and devices.
The memory model is an abstraction that aims to generalize across and
be adaptable to the different possible host and device
configurations. In this model, memory resides upon and is owned by
either the host or the device and is specified by declaring a memory
object. There are two different types of memory objects,
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-buffers}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{buffers}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-images}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{images}}}}.  Interaction of these memory
objects between the host and device is accomplished via an
{\hyperref[\detokenize{glossary:term-accessor}]{\sphinxtermref{\DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{accessor}}}}, which communicates the desired location of access,
such as host or device, and the particular mode of access, such as
read or write.

Consider a case where memory is allocated on the host through a
traditional malloc call. Once the memory is allocated on the host, a
buffer object is created, which enables the host allocated memory to be
communicated to the device. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} class communicates the type
and number of items of that type to be communicated to the device for
computation. Once a buffer is created on the host, the type of access
allowed on the device is communicated via an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{accessor}} object, which
specifies the type of access to the buffer. The general steps are
summarized as:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
Instantiate a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{image}} object.

The host or device memory for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{image}} is
allocated as part of the instantiation or is wrapped around
previously allocated memory on the host.

\item {} 
Instantiate an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{accessor}} object.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{accessor}} specifies the required location of access, such as
host or device, and the particular mode of access, such as read or
write. It represents dependencies between uses of memory objects.

\end{enumerate}

The following code sample is exercising different memory objects and
accessors.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}include \PYGZlt{}vector\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}include \PYGZlt{}CL/sycl.hpp\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n}{namespace} \PYG{n}{sycl} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{cl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{;}


\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}define SIZE 64}


\PYG{n+nb}{int} \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{std}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{array}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{SIZE}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{b}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{;}
     \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}


  \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{SIZE}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}


  \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{queue} \PYG{n}{d\PYGZus{}queue}\PYG{p}{;}


  \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{buffer}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}  \PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}device}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{buffer}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}  \PYG{n}{c\PYGZus{}device}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{image}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}  \PYG{n}{b\PYGZus{}device}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{b}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{image\PYGZus{}channel\PYGZus{}order}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{rgba}\PYG{p}{,}

    \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{accessor}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{read}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{target}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{constant\PYGZus{}buffer}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}res}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}device}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{cgh}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{accessor}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{float4}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{target}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{image}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{b\PYGZus{}res}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{b\PYGZus{}device}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{cgh}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}


    \PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{float4} \PYG{n}{init} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}


    \PYG{n}{cgh}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parallel\PYGZus{}for}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{ex1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nb}{id}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
      \PYG{n}{c\PYGZus{}res}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}res}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
      \PYG{n}{b\PYGZus{}res}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{int2}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{init}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Lines 8 and 9 contain the host allocations of arrays \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b}}, \&
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c}}. The declaration of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b}} is as a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{float4}} because it will be
accessed as an image on the device side.

\item {} 
Lines 27 and 28 create an accessor for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c\_device}} that has an
access mode of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{discard\_write}} and a target of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{global\_buffer}}.

\item {} 
Lines 29 and 30 create an accessor for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a\_device}} that has an
access mode of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read}} and a target of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{constant\_buffer}}.

\item {} 
Lines 31 and 32 create an accessor for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b\_device}} that has an
access mode of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{write}} and a target of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{image}}.

\end{itemize}

The accessors specify where and how the kernel will access these memory
objects. The runtime is responsible for placing the memory objects in
the correct location. Therefore, the runtime may copy data between host
and device to meet the semantics of the accessor target.

Designate accessor targets to optimize the locality of access for a
particular algorithm. For example, specify that local memory should be
employed if much of the kernel access would benefit from memory that
resides closer to the processing elements.

If the kernel attempts to violate the communicated accessor by either
attempting to write on a read accessor or read on a write accessor, a
compiler diagnostic is emitted. Not all combinations of access targets
and access modes are compatible. For details, see the SYCL
Specification.


\subsection{Memory Objects}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-objects:memory-objects}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-objects:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-objects::doc}}
Memory objects are either buffers or images.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Buffer object \sphinxhyphen{} a one\sphinxhyphen{}, two\sphinxhyphen{}, or three\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional array of elements.
Buffers can be accessed via lower level C++ pointer types. For
further information on buffers, see the SYCL Specification.

\item {} 
Image object \sphinxhyphen{} a formatted opaque memory object stored in a type
specific and optimized fashion. Access occurs through built\sphinxhyphen{}in
functions. Image objects typically pertain to pictures comprised of
pixels stored in a format such as RGB (red, green, blue intensity).
For further information on images, see the SYCL Specification.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Accessors}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/accessors:accessors}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/accessors:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/accessors::doc}}
Accessors provide access to buffers and images in the host or inside the
kernel and also communicate data dependencies between the application
and different kernels. The accessor communicates the data type, the
size, the target, and the access mode. To enable good performance, pay
particular attention to the target because the accessor specifies the
memory type from the choices in the SYCL memory model.

The targets associated with buffers are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
global\_buffer

\item {} 
host\_buffer

\item {} 
constant\_buffer

\item {} 
local

\end{itemize}

The targets associated with images are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
image

\item {} 
host\_image

\item {} 
image\_array

\end{itemize}

Image access must also specify a channel order to communicate the format
of the data being read. For example, an image may be specified as a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{float4}}, but accessed with a channel order of RGBA.

The access mode impacts correctness as well as performance and is one of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{write}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_write}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{discard\_write}},
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{discard\_read\_write}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{atomic}}. Mismatches in access mode and
actual memory operations such as a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{write}} to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} with access
mode \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read}} can result in compiler diagnostics as well as erroneous
program state. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{discard\_write}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{discard\_read\_write}} access
modes can provide performance benefits for some implementations. For
further details on accessors, see the SYCL Specification.


\subsection{Synchronization}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/synchronization:synchronization}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/synchronization:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/synchronization::doc}}
It is possible to access a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} without employing an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{accessor}},
however it should be the rare case. To do so safely, a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mutex\_class}}
should be passed when a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} is instantiated. For further details
on this method, see the SYCL Specification.
\subsubsection*{Access Targets}


\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart

\subsection{Unified Shared Memory}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/unified-shared-memory:unified-shared-memory}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/unified-shared-memory:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/unified-shared-memory::doc}}
An extension to the standard SYCL memory model is unified shared memory,
which enables the sharing of memory between the host and device without
explicit accessors in the source code. Instead, manage access and
enforces dependencies with explicit functions to wait on events or
signaling a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{depends\_on}} relationship between events.

Another characteristic of unified shared memory is that it provides a
C++ pointer\sphinxhyphen{}based alternative to the buffer programming model. Unified
shared memory provides both explicit and implicit models for managing
memory. In the explicit model, programmers are responsible for
specifying when data should be copied between memory allocations on the
host and allocations on a device. In the implicit model, the underlying
runtime and device drivers are responsible for automatically migrating
memory between the host and a device. Since unified shared memory does
not rely on accessors, dependencies between operations must be specified
using events. Programmers may either explicitly wait on event objects or
use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{depends\_on}} method inside a command group to specify a list
of events that must complete before a task may begin.


\subsection{Memory Types}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-types:memory-types}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-types:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/memory-types::doc}}

\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart
\centering
\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}[t]{|T|T|}
\hline
\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
Memory Type
&\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
Description
\\
\hline
Constant Memory
&
A region of global memory that remains constant during    the execution of a kernel. The host allocates and initializes memory   objects placed into constant memory.
\\
\hline
Global Memory
&
Accessible to all work\sphinxhyphen{}items in all work\sphinxhyphen{}groups.    Read/write, may be cached, persistent across kernel invocations.
\\
\hline
Local Memory
&
Shared between work\sphinxhyphen{}items in a single work\sphinxhyphen{}group and    inaccessible to work\sphinxhyphen{}items in other work\sphinxhyphen{}groups. Example: Shared   local memory on Intel HD Graphics 530
\\
\hline
Private Memory
&
A region of memory private to a work\sphinxhyphen{}item. Variables    defined in one work\sphinxhyphen{}item’s private memory are not visible to another   work\sphinxhyphen{}item. Example: Register File on Intel HD Graphics 530
\\
\hline
\end{tabulary}
\par
\sphinxattableend\end{savenotes}


\section{Kernel Programming Model}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/kernel-programming-model:kernel-programming-model}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/kernel-programming-model:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/kernel-programming-model::doc}}
The kernel programming model for oneAPI is based upon the SYCL* kernel
programming model. It enables explicit parallelism between the host and
device. The parallelism is explicit in the sense that the programmer
determines what code executes on the host and device; it is not
automatic. The kernel code executes on the accelerator. Programs
employing the oneAPI programming model support single source, meaning
the host code and device code can be in the same source file. However,
there are differences between the source code accepted in the host code
and the device code with respect to language conformance and language
features. The SYCL Specification defines in detail the required language
features for host code and device code. The following is a summary that
is specific to the oneAPI product.


\subsection{C++ Language Requirements}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/cpp-language-requirements:c-language-requirements}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/cpp-language-requirements:cpp-language-requirements}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/cpp-language-requirements::doc}}
The host code can be compiled by C++11 and later compilers and take
advantage of supported C++11 and later language features. The device
code requires a compiler that accepts all C++03 language features and
the following C++11 features:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Lamdba expressions

\item {} 
Variadic templates

\item {} 
Alias templates

\item {} 
rvalue references

\item {} 
std::function, std::string, std::vector

\end{itemize}

In addition, the device code cannot use the following features:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Virtual Functions

\item {} 
Virtual Inheritance

\item {} 
Exceptions handling \textendash{} throws and catches between host and device

\item {} 
Run Time Type Information (RTTI)

\item {} 
Object management employing new and delete operators

\end{itemize}

The device code is specified via one of three language constructs:
lambda expression, functor, or kernel class. The separation of host code
and device code via these language constructs is natural and
accomplished without language extensions. These different forms of
expressing kernels give the developer flexibility in enmeshing the host
code and device code. For example:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
To put the kernel code in line with the host code, consider employing
a lambda expression.

\item {} 
To have the device code separate from the host code, but still
maintain the single source property, consider employing a functor.

\item {} 
To port code from OpenCL programs or to ensure a more rigid
separation between host and device code, consider employing the
kernel class.

\end{itemize}

The Device code inside a lambda expression, functor, or kernel object
can then specify the amount of parallelism to request through several
mechanisms.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{single\_task}} \textendash{} execute a single instance of the kernel with a
single work item.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for}} \textendash{} execute a kernel in parallel across a range of
processing elements. Typically, this version of parallel\_for is
employed on “embarrassingly parallel” workloads.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for\_work\_group}} \textendash{} execute a kernel in parallel across a
hierarchical range of processing elements using local memory and
barriers.

\end{itemize}

The following code sample shows two combinations of invoking kernels:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
single\_task and C++ lambda (lines 33\sphinxhyphen{}40)

\item {} 
parallel\_for and functor (lines 8\sphinxhyphen{}20 and line 50)

\end{enumerate}

These constructs enclose the aforementioned kernel scope. For details,
see the SYCL Specification.

\subsection{Error Handling}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/error-handling:error-handling}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/error-handling:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/error-handling::doc}}
C++ exception handling is the basis for handling error conditions in the
programming model. Some restrictions on exceptions are in place due to
the asynchronous nature of host and device execution. For example, it is
not possible to throw an exception in kernel scope and catch it (in the
traditional sense) in application scope. Instead, there are a set of
restrictions and expectations in place when performing error handling.
These include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
At application scope, the full C++ exception handling mechanisms and
capability are valid as long as there is no expectation that
exceptions can cross to kernel scope.

\item {} 
At the command group scope, exceptions are asynchronous with respect
to the application scope. During command group construction, an
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{async\_handler}} can be declared to handle any exceptions occurring
during execution in the command group.

\end{itemize}

For further details on error handling, see the SYCL Specification.


\subsection{Fall Back}
\label{\detokenize{programming-model/fall-back:fall-back}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/fall-back:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-model/fall-back::doc}}
Typically, a command group is submitted and executed on the designated
command queue; however, there may be cases where the command queue is
unable to execute the group. In these cases, it is possible to specify a
fall back command queue for the command group to be executed upon. This
capability is handled by the runtime. This fallback mechanism is
detailed in the SYCL Specification.

The following code fails due to the size of the workgroup when executed
on Intel Processor Graphics, such as Intel HD Graphics 530. The SYCL
specification allows specifying a secondary queue as a parameter to the
submit function and this secondary queue is used if the device kernel
runs into issues with submission to the first device.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}include\PYGZlt{}CL/sycl.hpp\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}include\PYGZlt{}iostream\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}define N 1024}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}define M 32}
\PYG{n}{using} \PYG{n}{namespace} \PYG{n}{cl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{;}

\chapter{Language}
\label{\detokenize{language/index:language}}\label{\detokenize{language/index::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{\label{\detokenize{language/index:id1}}Todo:}
C++ version mininum
\end{sphinxadmonition}

{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-model/index:oneapi-programming-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Programming Model}}}} and subsections documented the C++
language features accepted in code at application scope and command
group scope in a DPC++ program.  Application scope and command group
scope includes the code that executes on the host. That section also
documented the C++ language features accepted in code at kernel scope
in a DPC++ program. Kernel scope is the code that executes on the
device. In general, the full capabilities of C++ are available at
application and command group scope. At kernel scope there are
limitations in accepted C++ due to the more limited, but focused,
capabilities of accelerators.

Compilers from different vendors have small eccentricities or
differences in their conformance to the C++ standard. The Intel oneAPI
DPC++ Compiler is a LLVM\sphinxhyphen{}based compiler and therefore drafts the
specific behavior of the LLVM\sphinxhyphen{}based compilers in accepting and creating
executables from C++ source code. To determine the specific LLVM version
that the Intel oneAPI DPC++ Compiler is based upon, use the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\textendash{}version}} option.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dpcpp} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{version}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{DPC}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{Compiler} \PYG{l+m+mf}{2021.1} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{2019.8}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.1010}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{Target}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{x86\PYGZus{}64}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pc}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{windows}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{msvc}
\PYG{n}{Thread} \PYG{n}{model}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{posix}
\PYG{n}{InstalledDir}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{:}\PYGZbs{}\PYG{n}{PROGRA}\PYG{o}{\PYGZti{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYGZbs{}\PYG{n}{INTELO}\PYG{o}{\PYGZti{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYGZbs{}\PYG{n}{compiler}\PYGZbs{}\PYG{n}{latest}\PYGZbs{}\PYG{n}{windows}\PYGZbs{}\PYG{n+nb}{bin}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Keywords}
\label{\detokenize{language/index:keywords}}
One of the design goals of DPC++ and SYCL is to not add keywords to the
language. The motivation is to enable easier compiler vendor adoption.
Whereas OpenCL C code and other accelerator\sphinxhyphen{}targeted languages require
proprietary keywords, DPC++ does not.


\section{Preprocessor Directives and Macros}
\label{\detokenize{language/index:preprocessor-directives-and-macros}}
Standard C++ preprocessing directives and macros are supported by the
compiler. In addition, the SYCL Specification defines the SYCL specific
preprocessor directives and macros.

The following preprocessor directives and macros are supported by the
compiler.


\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart
\centering
\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}[t]{|T|T|}
\hline
\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
Directive
&\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
Description
\\
\hline
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SYCL\_DUMP\_IMAGES}}
&
If true, instructs runtime to dump the device image
\\
\hline
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SYCL\_USE\_KERNEL\_SPV=\textless{}device binary\textgreater{}}}
&
Employ device binary to fulfill kernel launch request
\\
\hline
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SYCL\_PROGRAM\_BUILD\_OPTIONS}}
&
Used to pass additional options for device program    building.
\\
\hline
\end{tabulary}
\par
\sphinxattableend\end{savenotes}


\section{Standard Library Classes Required for the Interface}
\label{\detokenize{language/index:standard-library-classes-required-for-the-interface}}
Programming for oneAPI employs a variety of vectors, strings, functions,
and pointer objects common in STL programming.

The SYCL specification documents a facility to enable vendors to provide
custom optimized implementations. Implementations require aliases for
several STL interfaces. These are summarized as follows:
\index{vector\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{vector\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{string\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{string\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{function\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{function\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{mutex\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{mutex\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{shared\_ptr\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{shared\_ptr\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{unique\_ptr\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{unique\_ptr\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{weak\_ptr\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{weak\_ptr\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{hash\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{hash\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}\index{exception\_ptr\_class (C++ type)@\spxentry{exception\_ptr\_class}\spxextra{C++ type}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\item[{Template Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{T}} \textendash{} 

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{allocatorT}} \textendash{} 

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\chapter{Programming Interface}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/index:programming-interface}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/index:dpcpp-classes-class-templates-and-defines}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/index::doc}}
The Data Parallel C++ (DPC++) programming language and runtime consists
of a set of C++ classes, templates, and libraries used to express a
DPC++program. This chapter provides a summary of the key classes,
templates, and runtime libraries used to program.


\section{Header File}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/index:header-file}}

\section{Namespaces}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/index:namespaces}}

\section{Class Descriptions}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/index:class-descriptions}}
The following sections provide further details on these items. These
sections do not provide the exhaustive details found in the SYCL
Specification. Instead, these sections provide:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
A summary that includes a description and the purpose

\item {} 
Comments on the different constructors, if applicable

\item {} 
Member function information, if applicable

\item {} 
Special cases to consider with the DPC++ implementation compared to
the SYCL Specification

\end{itemize}

For further details on SYCL, see the \sphinxhref{https://www.khronos.org/registry/SYCL/specs/sycl-1.2.1.pdf}{SYCL
Specification}.

\paragraph{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{(constructor)}}}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/runtime/platform:constructor}}\begin{sphinxalltt}
platform();
explicit platform(cl\_platform\_id platformID); \begin{footnote}[1]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
Constructs a SYCL platform that retains an OpenCL id
\end{footnote}
explicit platform(const device\_selector \&deviceSelector); \begin{footnote}[2]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
Selects a platform that contains the desired device
\end{footnote}
\end{sphinxalltt}

Constructs a platform handle.

\subsection{Data Access}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/index:data-access}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/index::doc}}

\subsubsection{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{accessor}}}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/accessor:accessor}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/accessor::doc}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{template}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}
    \PYG{n}{typename} \PYG{n}{dataT}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nb}{int} \PYG{n}{dimensions}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{mode} \PYG{n}{accessmode}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{target} \PYG{n}{accessTarget} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{target}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{global\PYGZus{}buffer}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{placeholder} \PYG{n}{isPlaceholder} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{placeholder}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{false\PYGZus{}t}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{accessor}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

A DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{accessor}} encapsulates reading and writing memory objects
which can be buffers, images, or device local memory. Creating an
accessor requires a method to reference the desired access target.
Construction also requires the type of the memory object, the
dimensionality of the memory object, the access mode, and a placeholder
argument.

\paragraph{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{get\_size}}}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/accessor:get-size}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{size\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{const}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Description


\paragraph{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{get\_count}}}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/accessor:get-count}}\begin{sphinxalltt}
size\_t get\_size() const \begin{footnote}[1]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
No arguments
\end{footnote}
size\_t get\_size(int b) const \begin{footnote}[2]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
single argument
\end{footnote}
size\_t get\_size(int c, int d) const \begin{footnote}[3]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
2 arguments
\end{footnote}
\end{sphinxalltt}

Description

A common method of construction can employ the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_access}} method of
the memory object to specify the object and infer the other parameters
from that memory object.

See {\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-model/accessors:accessors}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Accessors}}}} for access modes and targets.

Placeholder accessors are those created independent of a command group
and then later associated with a particular memory object. Designation
of a placeholder accessor is communicated via the placeholder argument
set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{access::placeholder::true\_t}} if so and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{access::placeholder::false\_t}} otherwise.

Once an accessor is created, query member functions to review accessor
information. These member functions include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{is\_placeholder}} \textendash{} return true if accessor is a placeholder, not
yet associated with a memory object, false otherwise

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_size}} \textendash{} obtain the size (in bytes) of the memory object

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_count}} \textendash{} obtain the number of elements of the memory object

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the range of the memory object, where range is
a range class

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_offset}} \textendash{} obtain the offset of the memory object

\end{itemize}

An accessor can reference a subset of a memory object; this is the
offset of the accessor into the memory object.


\subsubsection{Atomic}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/atomic:atomic}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/atomic:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/atomic::doc}}
The DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{atomic}} class encapsulates operations and member
functions to guarantee synchronized access to data
values. Construction of an atomic object requires a reference to a
{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-interface/data/multi-pointer:multi-pointer}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Address Spaces}}}}. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}} is an abstraction on top of a
low\sphinxhyphen{}level pointer that enables efficient access across the host and
devices.

The atomic member functions are modeled after the C++ standard atomic
functions. They are documented more fully in the SYCL Specification and
include the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Store}} \textendash{} store a value

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Load}} \textendash{} load a value

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Exchange}} \textendash{} swap two values

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Compare\_exchange\_strong}} \sphinxhyphen{} compares two values for equality and
exchanges based on result

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_add}} \textendash{} add a value to the value pointed to by a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_sub}} \sphinxhyphen{} subtract a value from the value pointed to by a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_and}} \textendash{} bitwise and a value from the value pointed to by a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_or}} \sphinxhyphen{} bitwise or a value from the value pointed to by a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_xor}} \sphinxhyphen{} bitwise xor a value from the value pointed to by a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_min}} \textendash{} compute the minimum between a value and the value
pointed to by a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Fetch\_max}} \sphinxhyphen{} compute the maximum between a value and the value
pointed to by a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\_ptr}}

\end{itemize}

In addition to the member functions above, a set of functions with the
same capabilities are available acting on atomic types. These functions
are similarly named with the addition of “\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{atomic\_}}” prepended.
\index{memory\_order (C++ enum)@\spxentry{memory\_order}\spxextra{C++ enum}}

\subsubsection{Buffer}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/buffer:buffer}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/buffer:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/buffer::doc}}
A DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} encapsulates a 1\sphinxhyphen{}, 2\sphinxhyphen{}, or 3\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional array that is
shared between host and devices. Creating a buffer requires the number
of dimensions of the array as well as the type of the underlying data.

The class contains multiple constructors with different combinations of
ranges, allocators, and property lists.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The memory employed by the buffer is already existing in host memory.
In this case, a pointer to the memory is passed to the constructor.

\item {} 
Temporary memory is allocated for the buffer by employing the
constructors that do not include a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hostData}} parameter.

\item {} 
An allocator object is passed, which provides an alternative memory
allocator to be used for allocating the temporary memory for the
buffer. Special arguments, termed properties, can be provided to the
constructor for cases where host memory use is desired
(\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{use\_host\_ptr}}), use of the mutex\_class is desired
(\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{use\_mutex}}), and single context only (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{context\_bound}}) is
desired.

\end{itemize}

Once a buffer is allocated, query member functions to learn more. These
member functions include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the range object associated with the buffer

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_count}} \textendash{} obtain the number of elements in the buffer

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_size}} \textendash{} obtain the size of the buffer in bytes

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_allocator}} \textendash{} obtain the allocator that was provided in
creating the buffer

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{is\_sub\_buffer}} \textendash{} return if buffer is a sub\sphinxhyphen{}buffer or not

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Image}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/image:image}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/image:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/image::doc}}
A DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{image}} encapsulates a 1\sphinxhyphen{}, 2\sphinxhyphen{}, or 3\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional set of data
shared between host and devices. Creating an image requires the number
of dimensions of the array as well as the order and type of the
underlying data.

The class contains multiple constructors with different combinations of
orders, types, ranges, allocators, and property lists.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The memory employed by the image is already existing host memory. In
this case, a pointer to the memory is passed to the constructor.

\item {} 
Temporary memory is allocated for the image by employing the
constructors that do not include a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hostPointer}} parameter.

\item {} 
An allocator object is passed, which provides an alternative memory
allocator to be used for allocating the temporary memory for the
buffer.

\item {} 
When host memory use is desired (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{use\_host\_ptr}}), use of the
mutex\_class is desired (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{use\_mutex}}), and if a single context only
(\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{context\_bound}}) is desired, special arguments, termed properties,
are provided to the constructor.

\end{itemize}

Once a buffer is allocated, query member functions to learn more. These
member functions include
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the range object associated with the image

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_pitch}} \sphinxhyphen{} obtain the range associated with a one\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional
image

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_count}} \textendash{} obtain the number of elements in the image

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_size}} \textendash{} obtain the size of the image (in bytes)

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_allocator}} \textendash{} obtain the allocator that was provided in
creating the image

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_access}} \textendash{} obtain an accessor to the image with the specified
access mode and target

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Address Spaces}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/multi-pointer:address-spaces}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/multi-pointer:multi-pointer}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/data/multi-pointer::doc}}
The DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\sphinxhyphen{}pointer}} class encapsulates lower level pointers that
point to abstract device memory.

Constructors for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{multi\sphinxhyphen{}pointer}} class enable explicit mention of
the address space of the memory. The following lists the address space
with the appropriate identifier:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Global memory \textendash{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{global\_space}}

\item {} 
Local memory \textendash{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{local\_space}}

\item {} 
Constant memory \textendash{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{constant\_space}}

\item {} 
Private memory \textendash{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{private\_space}}

\end{itemize}

The constructors can also be called in an unqualified fashion for cases
where the location will be known later.

Member functions include standard pointer operations such as ++
(increment), \textendash{} (decrement), + (plus), and \textendash{} (minus). A prefetch
function is also specified to aid in optimization and is implementation
defined.

Conversion operations are also available to convert between the raw
underlying pointer and an OpenCL program’s C pointer for
interoperability. Consult the SYCL Specification for complete details.
\index{access::address\_space (C++ enum)@\spxentry{access::address\_space}\spxextra{C++ enum}}

\subsubsection{Samplers}

\subsection{Expressing Parallelism}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/index:expressing-parallelism}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/index::doc}}

\subsubsection{Range}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/range:range}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/range:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/range::doc}}
The DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{range}} class encapsulates the iteration domain of a
work\sphinxhyphen{}group or the entire kernel dispatch. Constructors for a range
object take one, two, or three arguments of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{size\_t}} dependent on the
dimensionality of the range, either one, two, or three dimensions
respectively.

Member functions include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get}} \textendash{} obtain the specified dimension

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{size}} \textendash{} obtain the size of the range

\end{itemize}

Additional functions allow construction of new ranges from old ranges
with additional operations on the range. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Range\PYGZlt{}2\PYGZgt{} +() const??
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\index{range (C++ class)@\spxentry{range}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\subsubsection{Nd\_range}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-range:nd-range}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-range:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-range::doc}}
The DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}} class encapsulates the iteration domain of the
work\sphinxhyphen{}groups and kernel dispatch. It is the entire iteration space of
data that a kernel may operation upon. The constructor for an
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}} object take the global range, local range, and an optional
offset.

Member functions include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the global range

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_local\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the local range

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_group\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the number of groups in each dimension
of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_offset}} \textendash{} obtain the offset

\end{itemize}
\index{nd\_range (C++ class)@\spxentry{nd\_range}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-range:_CPPv4I_iE8nd_range}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysigline{template\textless{}int \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{dimensions}} = 1\textgreater{}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}}}%

\subsubsection{ID}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/id:id}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/id:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/id::doc}}
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{id}} class encapsulates a vector of dimensions that identify an
index into a global or local range. Constructors for the class take one
to three integer arguments representing a one, two, and three dimension
ID. Each integer argument specifies the size of the dimension. ID
objects can also be constructed as a placeholder where the dimension is
unspecified and set to zero by default. Construction can also be based
upon the dimension of an existing range or item.

The class supports operations such as + (plus), \sphinxhyphen{} (minus), and many
more. Consult the SYCL Specification for complete details.
\index{id (C++ class)@\spxentry{id}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\subsubsection{Item}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/item:item}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/item:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/item::doc}}
A DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{item}} encapsulates a function object executing on an
individual data point in a DPC++ range. When a kernel is executed, it is
associated with an individual item in a range and acts upon it. This
association is accomplished implicitly, by the runtime. Therefore, there
are no user callable constructors; a DPC++ item is created when a kernel
is instantiated.

The member functions of the item class pertain to determining the
relationship between the item and the enclosing range:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_id}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the work item in the iteration
space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the range associated with the item

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_offset}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the item in the n\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional
space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_linear\_id}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the item converting the
n\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional space into one

\end{itemize}
\index{item (C++ class)@\spxentry{item}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/item:_CPPv4I_i_bE4item}}%
\pysigstartmultiline

\end{description}\end{quote}
\end{quote}

\subsubsection{Nd\_item}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-item:nd-item}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-item:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/nd-item::doc}}
A DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item}} encapsulates a function object executing on an
individual data point in a DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}}. When a kernel is
executed, it is associated with an individual item in a range and acts
upon it. This association is accomplished implicitly, by the runtime.
Therefore, there are no user callable constructors; a DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item}}
is created when a kernel is instantiated.

The member functions of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item}} class pertain to determining the
relationship between the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item}} and the enclosing range:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_id}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the work item in the
iteration space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_linear\_id}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the work item in a
linear representation of the global iteration space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_local\_id}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the item in the current
work\sphinxhyphen{}group

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_local\_linear\_id}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the item in a linear
representation of the current work\sphinxhyphen{}group

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_group}} \textendash{} obtain the position of the item in the overall
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_group\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the number of work\sphinxhyphen{}groups in the
iteration space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the range representing the dimensions
of the global iteration space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_local\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the range representing the dimension of
the current work\sphinxhyphen{}group

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_offset}} \textendash{} obtain an id that represents the offset between a
work\sphinxhyphen{}item representation between local and global iteration space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_nd\_range}} \textendash{} obtain the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_range}} from the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{nd\_item}}

\end{itemize}

The class also includes a member function, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{async\_work\_group\_copy}},
which can copy a range of items asynchronously.

\subsubsection{Group}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/group:group}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/group:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/group::doc}}
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{group}} class encapsulates work\sphinxhyphen{}group functionality. Constructors
are not user\sphinxhyphen{}callable; objects are created as a by\sphinxhyphen{}product of a call to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for\_work\_group.}}

Once a group object has been instantiated, query various properties of
the object by calling several member functions including:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_id}} \textendash{} obtains the index of the work\sphinxhyphen{}group

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_range}} \textendash{} obtain a range that represents the work\sphinxhyphen{}items
across the index space

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_local\_range}} \textendash{} obtain a range that represents the work\sphinxhyphen{}items
in a work\sphinxhyphen{}group

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_group\_range}} \textendash{} obtain a range representing the dimensions of
the current work\sphinxhyphen{}group

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_linear\_id}} \textendash{} obtain a linear version of the work\sphinxhyphen{}group id

\end{itemize}

Definitions of global range and local range are in the SYCL
Specification glossary. In brief, a global range is the overall number
of work\sphinxhyphen{}items in the index space. A local range is the number of
work\sphinxhyphen{}items in a work\sphinxhyphen{}group.
\index{group (C++ class)@\spxentry{group}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/group:_CPPv4I_iE5group}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysigline{template\textless{}int \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{dimensions}} = 1\textgreater{}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{group}}}%
\pysigstopmultiline~\index{group::get\_id (C++ function)@\spxentry{group::get\_id}\spxextra{C++ function}}\index{group::get\_id (C++ function)@\spxentry{group::get\_id}\spxextra{C++ function}}

\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/range:_CPPv4I_iE5range}]{\sphinxcrossref{range}}}\textless{}{\hyperref[\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/group:_CPPv4I_iE5group}]{\sphinxcrossref{dimensions}}}\textgreater{} \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_global\_range}}}{}{ \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{const}}}%

\subsubsection{Device Event}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/device-event:device-event}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/device-event:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/device-event::doc}}
The DPC++ \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{device\_event}} class encapsulates wait objects within
kernels. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{device\_event}} objects are used to coordinate
asynchronous operations in kernels. The constructor and its arguments
are unspecified and implementation dependent. The wait member function
causes execution to stop until the operation associated with the wait is
complete.
\index{device\_event (C++ class)@\spxentry{device\_event}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/device-event:_CPPv412device_event}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{device\_event}}}%
\pysigstopmultiline~\index{device\_event::wait (C++ function)@\spxentry{device\_event::wait}\spxextra{C++ function}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/device-event:_CPPv4N12device_event4waitEv}}%
\pysigstartmultiline
\pysiglinewithargsret{void \sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{wait}}}{}{}%
\pysigstopmultiline
\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}



\subsubsection{Command Group Handler}
\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/command-group-handler:command-group-handler}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/command-group-handler:id1}}\label{\detokenize{programming-interface/parallelism/command-group-handler::doc}}
The command group handler class encapsulates the actions of the command
group, namely the marshaling of data and launching of the kernels on the
devices.

There are no user callable constructors; construction is accomplished by
the oneAPI runtime. Consider the example code below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{d\PYGZus{}queue}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{submit}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{handler} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{cgh}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
         \PYG{n}{auto} \PYG{n}{c\PYGZus{}res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{c\PYGZus{}device}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}access}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{access}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cgh}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
         \PYG{n}{cgh}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parallel\PYGZus{}for}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{ex1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{a\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sycl}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nb}{id}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
           \PYG{n}{c\PYGZus{}res}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}
         \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
       \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

In the example, the accessor, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{c\_res}}, is obtained from the device and
takes a command group handler as a parameter, in this case \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cgh}}. The
kernel dispatch itself is a member function of the command group
handler. In this case, a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for}} is called. The kernel dispatch
API has multiple calls including \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for}},
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parallel\_for\_work\_group}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{single\_task}}.

There is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{set\_args}} function employed for passing arguments to an
OpenCL™ kernel for interoperability.
\index{handler (C++ class)@\spxentry{handler}\spxextra{C++ class}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection*{Kernel dispatch API}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Note: In all Kernel dispatch functions,
when using a functor with a globally visible name
the template parameter:”typename kernelName” can be ommitted
and the kernelType can be used instead.
\end{sphinxadmonition}
